title: Why is the game dying? Because it doesn't matter how good YOU are; the WORST player on team matters.
body:
This season, it doesn't matter how hard you shit on your laner and how big you can push that advantage. If you don't spoonfeed that top AND bot lane from your spot in midlane, then you will lose the game. Can't tell you how many times I have punished a mid laner into complete uselessness, but at the 15 minute mark I have a 0-10 (or worse) bot lane AND/OR top lane who ruins the game.

In the event you get people that go even, then your teammates refuse to listen to pings and/or calls and they fight when they shouldn't and won't fight when they should and throw the game. This game blows.

You need to know how to adjust to your weakest link, the way a pack of wolves matches the pace of its slowest member. In the same way three wolves struggle to bring down a moose when they run ahead of two packmates, a team of three or four will struggle if it's playing out in front of its fifth member.

That said, you're absolutely right. This game blows.

First of all, let's get this out of the way: Wolves invite outsiders to their pack. It happens. It's not ideal and it's not commonplace, but if there's a sense that the pack is understaffed for whatever reason when an outsider wanders into the territory, the will absolutely hunt with that outsider. So yes, wolves can in fact join another pack.

More pertinently, we're talking about different things. You're discussing the long term "survival" of carrying yourself to high ELO. I'm discussing the short term "survival" of winning a game in which you have a poignantly bad player on your team.
Uh no, wolves are extremely territorial and RARELY tolerate one in their territory. So again, you are wrong. A wolfs pack is the parents and their offspring, they rarely if ever bring in outsiders.

Rarely. Exceptionally. Not "absolutely never". I believe I stated it was a rarity; the point was that it happens, not that it's a benchmark behavior. If the pack is small and starving, winter is coming, and an outsider is looking for succor, wolves will absolutely allow for an extra hunter. It won't be a fun time for the newcomer, but they'll allow it.
Yes and people are rarely born without hands. That doesn't mean society needs to change and alter everything to fit those anomolies.

It doesn't, and yet it does so anyway. We've dedicated tens of millions in prosthetic limb research and development. This lends itself to an argument I made in another post where a man was offended by my allusion to wolves: The more humanity as adapted and grown, the more it has _chosen_ to support the weakest among them. We could apply all that time, money and manpower that goes into prosthetics research into... any number of fields propping up the best of mankind. Space programs. State pensions for beloved singers and actors. Infrastructure projects that allow entrepreneurs private roadways that allow them to get to and from their places of business more efficiently, leading to greater profits and greater private sector yields.

But instead, humanity spends this time and money helping people without hands, or feet, or limbs, to function better in society. Because one day, that kid without hands might go on with their prosthetic appendages to author some society-shaping treatise. Or to compose music that alters a generation's mindset. Or to be a superb firefighter who saves dozens of lives.

Abandoning the weak is nonsense, and wolves recognized this ages before humans did. Fortunately, humans are catching on.
Darwin, Survival of the fittest.
